title: Badgers blank St. Cloud State
text:
Badgers blank St. Cloud State By Special to the Journal Sentinel Oct. 18, 2015 (0) Comments 
The University of Wisconsin women's hockey team likes the look of all those zeros on the scoreboard. 
The Badgers earned their fourth straight shutout by beating St. Cloud State, 2-0, on Saturday at Herb Brooks National Hockey Center in St. Cloud, Minn. 
Megan Miller, who transferred to UW after two seasons at Boston College, turned away 14 shots to notch her first shutout with the Badgers (6-0, 4-0 WCHA). 
"It was a great performance by Megan," UW head coach Mark Johnson said. "You're looking for opportunities to play people, and it's certainly what we looked at today in giving Megan a chance. It was a tight game and I'm happy for her, it certainly builds her confidence as we go through the rest of the season." 
Erika Sowchuk scored her first goal of the season to give UW a 1-0 lead over the Huskies (2-4, 0-4) two minutes into the second period. 
Anne Pankowski added her eighth goal of the season in the third period after St. Cloud State had pulled its goalie. MEN'S SOCCER 
Creighton 3, Marquette 1: Kelmend Islami, a former South Milwaukee standout, scored the lone goal for the Golden Eagles against the Bluejays at Valley Fields. 
Wright State 1, UW-Milwaukee 0: Jackson Dietrich came off the bench to score the only goal for the Raiders in a victory over the Panthers at Engelmann Field. WOMEN'S SOCCER 
UW-Milwaukee 1, Detroit 0: The Panthers earned the victory when a Titans defender knocked the ball into her own goal in the 47th minute. VOLLEYBALL 
Marquette 3, St. John's 0: Taylor Louis had 20 kills as the Golden Eagles (14-7, 6-3 Big East) swept the Red Storm (14-10, 4-5), 25-17, 25-19, 25-14, at the Al McGuire Center. 
Teal Schnurr added six kills for MU and hit .364 in the match, while Sara Blasier handed out a match-high 31 assists. 
The Golden Eagles hit .330 in the match. They held St. John's to a .131 hitting percentage with no blocks. Â© 2015 , Journal Sentinel Inc. All rights reserved.
